I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 
to the Republic of Palau for the COVID-19 Response for Affected Poor and Vulnerable Groups 
Project. The report also describes the proposed administration of a grant to be provided by the 
Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction (JFPR) and a grant to be provided by the Ireland Trust Fund 
for Building Climate Change and Disaster Resilience in Small Island Developing States (Ireland 
Trust Fund) and if the Board approves the proposed grant, I, acting under the authority delegated 
to me by the Board, approve the administration of each of these grants. 
 
2.  The project aims to address the needs of poor and vulnerable groups affected by the 
coronavirus disease (COVID-19). All outputs are aligned with the outcome of improving the 
capability of vulnerable groups to withstand the impacts of COVID-19 by providing immediate 
assistance to these groups while positioning them to achieve higher levels of economic and social 
well-being post-COVID-19. The project will (i) implement welfare support to highly at-risk older 
people and persons with disabilities (PWD), (ii) deliver food security and income-generating 
support to small agricultural producers, and (iii) implement multidisciplinary responses to address 
family violence and gender-based violence (GBV). 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  Although  Palau  has  only  2  confirmed  COVID-19  cases,  the  pandemic  has  had  a 
devastating impact on its tourism-dependent economy.1 The estimated population of Palau is at 
17,934 in 2020.2 An extended border closure began in March 2020 and has brought tourism to a 
standstill, resulting in the loss of more than 3,200 jobs, or nearly 30% of formal employment for 
both local and foreign workers. An estimated 1,200 of these lost jobs were held by women.3 Real 
per capita household incomes are projected to fall by 22.6% as a result of COVID-19, which could 
increase the basic needs poverty rate from 19.4% in 2014 to 27.9% in FY2021.4 Although the 
government  took  prompt  action  and  was  able  to  attenuate  severe  hardship  through  its 
Coronavirus Relief One Stop Shop (CROSS) Act, persons with pre-existing vulnerabilities are 
being disproportionately impacted by the economic impacts of COVID-19. These groups include 
older people and PWD, the poor, small agricultural producers, and survivors of family violence 
and GBV. 
 
4.  Heightened  vulnerability  among  marginalized  groups.  Older  people  and  PWD, 
particularly those with pre-existing conditions, experience heightened vulnerability because of 
COVID-19  mobility  restrictions  and  their  dependency  on  caregivers.  The  homebound  are 
particularly vulnerable to serious illness or death in the event of a COVID-19 outbreak in Palau 
because of their age and chronic health conditions. Many older people and PWD also depend on 
their extended families for financial support, which has been adversely impacted by reduced

infection outside of Palau. There is still no local transmission of COVID-19. Palau Ministry of Health. Corona Virus 
2019 (COVID-19) Situation Report. 14 June 2021(accessed 17 June 2021). 
2   Secretariat of the Pacific Community. 2019. Palau | Statistics for Development Division (spc.int). 
3  Graduate School USA, Economic Monitoring and Analysis Program. 2020. Where Do We Go from Here? Updating

4  Asian Development Bank (ADB) estimates. With real per capita incomes increasing by a cumulative 11.4% between

2 
household earnings triggered by the pandemic. There are an estimated 2,288 senior citizens in 
Palau, representing 13% of the total population, and this proportion is projected to increase 
substantially  in  the  future.5  Approximately  200  older  people  and  PWD  are  registered  as 
homebound in the country.6 Although 75% of older people are either employed or receive social 
security, many early retirees receive only modest payments.7 Of households headed by senior 
citizens, the share who live below the basic needs poverty line is 16.2% in urban areas and 19.5% 
in rural areas.8 The share of households headed by senior citizens without an income is highest 
in rural Babeldaob (54%), followed by Koror-Airai urban (27%) and outlying states (19%).9 
Government services such as midday meals for senior citizens are only available in the Koror-
Airai region and reach only about 2% of the eligible population (footnote 9). 
 
5.  Adverse  economic  impacts  affecting  poor  and  smallholder  producers.  Palau’s 
economy is dominated by the formal wage and salary sector, which employs 83% of the labor 
force and generates 65% of household income.10 Despite the dominance of the formal sector, 
small-scale production of agricultural and marine products is a source of income for one-third of 
households (footnote 8). Rural households are 50% more likely to live in poverty than urban 
households. Because of rising sea levels, saltwater inundation is also a serious problem for 
farmers in low-lying areas. About 25% of rural households have reported significant impacts from 
the COVID-19 economic slowdown; and 70% of impacted households have been primarily 
affected by reduced market sales.11 Because most small producers are unregistered, many lack 
records to document their losses and, hence, have experienced difficulty qualifying for temporary 
unemployment benefits. About 3,364 persons have received full or partial unemployment benefits 
under one of the three COVID-19 temporary assistance programs: the United States federal 
Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security programs; CROSS temporary employment; and 
CROSS unemployment assistance. Of this number, only about 1.5% are small producers and 
9.2% are market vendors.12 
 
6.  Risk of increased domestic and gender-based violence. Estimates of GBV in Palau 
show that, out of a population of 6,503 women, (i) 520 experience domestic violence perpetuated 
by an intimate partner in their lifetime, (ii) 384 experience violence perpetuated by a non-partner 
in their lifetime, and (iii) more than 900 are impacted by violence each year.13 On average,

3

year.14 This indicates that, prior to COVID-19, there was already a significant unmet need for 
support. Since COVID-19, there have been anecdotal reports of increased domestic violence, 
and the number of cases reported to the police rose by more than 200% from March 2020 to July 
2020. In 2012, Palau enacted the Family Protection Act (FPA), which seeks to address all forms 
of family violence, and to create a seamless system of response from law enforcement and the 
judiciary, health, and social sectors. However, a review of FPA implementation in 2017 identified 
service gaps in case management, counseling, access to temporary housing, and prevention.15 
The highest priority gap in the FPA implementation plan is a lack of holistic case management 
support for family and GBV survivors. 
 
7.  Limited social protection programs. The social protection sector in Palau primarily 
comprises social insurance, which only provides direct benefits to those in formal employment.16 
In  2015, the  government’s formal social  assistance  expenditures  were  only  0.7%  of  gross 
domestic product with limited assistance for older people, PWD, and children with special needs 
(footnote 16). As a result, the social protection sector was poorly positioned to respond sufficiently 
to the impacts of COVID-19 on vulnerable groups. Finding ways to further strengthen and expand 
existing social protection programs in Palau is critical to respond immediately to vulnerable groups 
during a pandemic and develop a more adaptive social protection system for the future. 
 
8.  Alignment with  government  strategies. The  project  will  support the government’s 
comprehensive COVID-19 response strategy by expanding social assistance to mitigate the 
short-term economic impacts of COVID-19 while building the resilience of beneficiaries against 
future shocks. The project is aligned with Palau’s medium- and long-term poverty reduction 
strategies. The Palau 2020 National Master Development Plan targets increased economic 
growth per capita on a sustainable basis, and shared the benefits of economic growth equitably.17 
Further, the latest medium-term development strategy—Actions for Palau’s Future—includes a 
vision of “life with dignity.”18 Specific goals include (i) ensuring that the basic needs of all of Palau’s 
residents are met; (ii) reducing vulnerability by preserving safety nets represented by the Palauan 
ethic of sharing and caring, and universal access to productive land and sea resources; and (iii) 
providing compassionate and timely assistance to people who fall through the safety nets. 
 
9.  Lessons  and  alignment  with  ADB  strategy.  The  project  is  included  in  Asian 
Development Bank’s (ADB) country operations business plan and is fully aligned with the Pacific 
Approach which focuses on addressing vulnerability to external shocks.19 The project is also 
aligned with ADB’s Strategy 2030 operational priorities of (i) addressing remaining poverty and 
reducing  inequalities;  (ii)  accelerating  progress  in  gender  equality;  (iii)  promoting  rural 
development and food security; and (iv) tackling climate change, building climate and disaster 
resilience,  and  enhancing  environmental  sustainability.20  The  project  design  integrates  key 
lessons from ADB’s response to the COVID-19 crisis, such as the need to ensure ownership and

B.  Project Description 
 
10.  The project is aligned with the following impact: adverse impacts of COVID-19 on poor 
and vulnerable groups are mitigated, and the social and economic resilience of these groups is 
strengthened. The project will have the following outcome: capabilities of poor and vulnerable 
households to withstand further impacts of COVID-19 improved.22 The project is estimated to have 
1,650 direct beneficiaries, an estimated additional 1,400 frontline workers who will be trained on 
GBV referral pathways, and at least 12,000 people to be covered by a GBV prevention campaign. 
 
11.  Output  1:  Welfare  support  for  highly  at-risk  older  people  and  persons  with 
disabilities implemented. This output will respond to the immediate physical, mental, social, and 
environmental needs of low-income, homebound older people and PWD. It will provide assistance 
through (i) gender-responsive case management that facilitates access to the full range of 
services available in the community such as health care, social programs, and legal and family 
protection;23 (ii) community-based wellness promotion to enhance social well-being and alleviate 
loneliness among older people and PWD; (iii) training for family and community caregivers on 
care and support for vulnerable people and PWD;24 (iv) help in developing home gardens by 
providing family caregivers with seedlings, planting materials, and know-how to cultivate and use 
produce to meet nutritional needs; and (v) support for home improvements and adaptations to 
ensure healthy, safe, and accessible living conditions. The output will help the government deliver 
more effective social protection services to older people and PWD through holistic support that 
strengthens the capacity of individuals, their families, and their caregivers to address a range of 
factors that undermine quality of life, while encouraging deeper collaboration with community-
based organizations and volunteers to strengthen existing social protection services. This output 
is also envisaged to contribute to amending the Health Care Fund to include paying community-
based caregivers. Beneficiaries will be prioritized based on functional capacity (with bedridden 
persons or those with limited mobility); income status (no income, income below the national 
poverty line, or decreased household income because of COVID-19), and urgency of their care 
needs.25 
 
12.  Output  2:  Food  security  and  income-generating  support  delivered  to  small 
agricultural producers. The Palau Visitors Authority (PVA) and Bureau of Agriculture (BOA), 
working closely with partners,26 will support small agriculture producers to increase production 
and augment earnings while reducing vulnerability to climate change, particularly sea level rise, 
by promoting upland taro production.27 Activities under the output are (i) the promotion of food

of cultured  seedlings  to farmers;28  (ii)  the  provision  of seed  grants,  extension support  and 
business support training for selected women’s farming cooperatives to expand to dryland taro 
production and to encourage them to adopt improved business management practices; (iii) the

processing facility; and (iv) through the food processing facility, the provision of a guaranteed 
market for purchasing raw agriculture products from small agriculture producers. The center will 
not only sustain project interventions but help add value by facilitating the production of new 
products, including taro chips, ice cream, and taro flour.29 Sales of processed food products will 
link with existing retail outlets, restaurants, and caterers. New value-added products developed 
through the food processing center will not only serve the domestic market but also promote 100% 
Palau-sourced goods in the tourism market.30 This is envisaged to promote community–tourism 
linkages in the medium- to long-term. The output will focus on small agriculture women producers 
on the island of Babeldaob.31 Key selection criteria for women’s farming cooperatives include at 
least 25% of its members are low-income, significantly impacted by the COVID-19 economic 
slowdown, or single-parent households; or it has proposed a plan to leverage seed grant funds to 
serve  low-income  or  single-parent  households  in  their  community.  The  women’s  farming 
cooperatives  will  enter  into  a  memorandum  of  agreement  with the  Ministry  of  Agriculture, 
Fisheries and Environment through the BOA on the use of seed grants.32 
 
13.  Output 3: Multidisciplinary responses to address family and gender-based violence 
implemented. This output will address two priority gaps in the current response to family and 
GBV, which are at risk of being aggravated by the pandemic: (i) a lack of integrated case 
management support to help survivors navigate the legal, health, and social service systems; and 
(ii) a lack of sustained prevention-oriented communications. The project will address these gaps 
by (i) delivering integrated case management support for survivors, including a free 24-hour 
hotline, crisis counseling, and multisectoral referral pathways;33 and (ii) implementing a social 
marketing campaign that both informs key service providers of available services and referral 
pathways, and helps change community social norms on GBV. The project will help ensure that 
survivors of family and GBV, especially during the pandemic, receive high-quality, culturally 
sensitive,  non-judgmental  services in  a manner that fosters self-respect  and  independence 
through the involvement of nongovernment organizations (NGOs). As survivors gain trust in these

C.  Value Added by ADB 
 
14.  The rapid assessment of COVID-19 impacts on vulnerable groups, through ADB’s regional 
technical assistance for Strengthening Social Protection in the Pacific, helped inform the project 
scope.34 The project seeks to add value by (i) providing integrated COVID-19 responses that 
target vulnerable groups and complement other ADB support in the country, including the COVID-
19  Pandemic  Response  Option  and  emergency  support  through  the Asia  Pacific  Disaster 
Response Fund;35 (ii) addressing immediate needs and existing gaps in COVID-19 responses, 
while positioning beneficiaries to achieve higher levels of economic, health, and social well-being; 
(iii) not only assisting direct beneficiaries, but also building the capacity of their support groups 
including  family  members  and  communities;  and  (iv)  building  on  existing  social  protection 
programs and other services to expand them to vulnerable groups, including taro farmers whose 
livelihoods are being threatened by sea level rise. The project also includes gender-transformative 
features  to  build  women’s  resilience  to  similar  shocks.  Lessons  from  the  project  will  be 
disseminated though knowledge products and regional Pacific events to be facilitated by ADB’s 
regional technical assistance for Strengthening Social Protection in the Pacific (footnote 34).

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
22.  While the family and clan systems in Palau remain strong, they are slowly being eroded 
by social change. The project incorporates several innovations to help respond to gaps in social 
protection systems. Output 1 focuses on seamless, holistic services that consider the overall 
health and well-being of homebound older people and PWD. Qualitative data collection, including 
the use of photovoice techniques, will document baseline conditions and make it possible to track

9 
project impacts across the life of the project.37 Output 2 will implement a novel approach for 
addressing  a  nexus  of  development  issues  in  agriculture,  food  security,  and tourism,  with 
particular benefits for smallholder women producers affected by the pandemic. Output 3 will 
strengthen  the  implementation  of  Palau’s  FPA  by  piloting  integrated  “wrap-around”  case 
management services delivered through an NGO.38 Research suggests that survivors are more 
comfortable seeking help outside the government sector, and that an NGO will be more flexible 
than a government office in responding to client needs. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial Viability 
 
23.  A qualitative assessment indicates that the project activities will significantly benefit the 
poor and vulnerable in Palau.39 Output 1 is expected to improve beneficiaries’ physical and mental 
health and social well-being by (i) reducing the risk of illness and feelings of isolation, (ii) providing 
access to nutritious food, and (iii) providing a form of community wellness check to ensure the 
continued good health of vulnerable residents. Output 2 will help boost local food security and 
generate income. It will also generate incomes for smallholder producers from guaranteed sales 
of their produce at fair market prices to the food processing center, and promote the integration 
of healthy local produce into household diets and restaurant menus. The nursery and food 
processing center will also provide opportunities for internships and placements for female 
students to support entry into more skilled work. Output 3 is expected to help reduce the severity 
and incidence of family violence and GBV through improved case management and increased 
public awareness. Improved response and referral mechanisms will also help facilitate survivors’ 
recovery from trauma and allow them to develop practical life skills to live independently. All 
project outputs were assessed for financial sustainability rather than financial viability. Outputs 1 
and 3, and the plant nursery under output 2 will generate no revenue, while the objective for the 
food processing facility under output 2 is cost recovery rather than profit.40 
 
C.  Sustainability 
 
24.  Output 1 will expand the MHHS’s social assistance to older people and PWD. The project’s 
holistic approach will provide inputs to the policy on aging as mandated by Public Law 10-51, 
National Policy on Care for the Aging (enacted in February 2020). Under output 1, the project will 
also help develop partnerships between state governments and community-based organizations 
to support the continuity of services after the end of the project. In the medium term, the 
government is expected to amend the Health Care Fund to include paying community-based 
caregivers assisting certified recipients.41 The plant nursery under output 2 is expected to be 
financially sustainable because of ongoing government support: the BOA will manage the nursery 
and has indicated its commitment to continue providing support beyond project completion since 
the nursery is already part of its programs, in line with its mandate to develop the agriculture

sustainable. Preliminary estimates suggest that sales revenues will be sufficient to offset costs of

Ministry of Finance (MOF) has indicated that the government will provide support as needed. 
Output 3 provides an alternative model for delivering services to survivors of family violence and

family violence and GBV. If successful, the MHHS will seek resources under the FPA to continue 
intervention when grant funding ends. 
 
D.  Governance 
 
25.  The pre-mitigation financial management risk assessment for the MOF is low. The MOF 
has a fully functioning financial management structure that manages the government’s financial 
aspects and has experience implementing donor-funded projects, including those financed by 
ADB. The pre-mitigation financial management risk for the implementing agencies is substantial. 
Key financial management risks include low capacity in financial management systems, the 
absence of an internal audit function, and a lack of familiarity with ADB disbursement procedures 
and reporting requirements. As the implementing agencies operate on budgetary allocations, they 
merely monitor their expenditures against the budget provided. The MOF and implementing 
agencies will implement an action plan as key measures to address these deficiencies (Table 4). 
 
26.  The MOF and implementing agencies have sufficient procurement experience under 
national  law,  including  the  evaluation  of  technical  proposals  and  monitoring  of  contract 
performance.  However,  since  they  lack  experience  with  multilateral  development  bank 
procurement procedures, the procurement risk is assessed as medium. A procurement specialist 
will be recruited under the project management unit to help with procurement and contract 
management in accordance with ADB regulations. ADB will provide training and intermittent 
mentoring to the project management unit on procurement guidelines and procedures. ADB’s 
Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed with the 
implementing agencies and MOF. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures 
are described in the PAM (footnote 36). ADB conducted integrity due diligence on the PVA and 
the members of its board of directors and key management.42 They do not appear to constitute 
significant or potentially significant integrity risk. ADB has obtained reasonable assurance that the 
PVA was not established and is not being used for money laundering or terrorism financing in the 
project jurisdiction. 
 
E.  Poverty, Social, and Gender 
 
27.  Nearly one in five seniors live below the national poverty line, 15% live with a disability, 
and 75% live with one or more chronic health conditions.43 Welfare assistance for older people 
and PWD will not only address their existing needs but also prevent the causes of rapidly

household income because of COVID-19 puts vulnerable groups, especially poor households and 
smallholder producers, at risk of falling deeper into poverty.44 The food security and income-
generating component will provide immediate support to these groups, while helping them build 
economic resilience to withstand further shocks. The project is categorized as gender equity 
theme. Gender elements under output 1 include expanding and strengthening social assistance 
for 150 homebound older people and PWD (55% women); developing gender-responsive case

(60% women) through increased access to taro seedlings; supporting at least 300 women farmers 
to increase production and income; and providing internships enabling women students to gain 
technical agricultural skills. Output 3 includes such activities as developing and rolling out family 
and GBV case management services, training on services and referral pathways for frontline 
workers and women’s organizations, and a national social marketing campaign. 
 
F.  Safeguards 
 
28.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project’s safeguard 
categories are as follows.45 
 
29.  Environment. The project is category C for environmental safeguards. Outputs 1 and 3 
involve no civil works. Output 2 involves minor renovations to existing structures to house the 
nursery at the BOA center in Nekken and to house the agriculture support center comprising the 
food processing facility and plant distribution nursery. Renovation works will be limited to existing 
structures and will not involve any earthmoving activities. State building permits will be required 
and will be issued after the nominated contractor prepares a basic construction environmental 
management plan as stipulated in the project’s grant agreement. While there may be small-scale 
secondary processing during project operation, such activity will not be on an industrial scale, with 
the project using basic and simple machines. Thus, the waste stream will be insignificant and 
adequately handled through the local municipal authority. Overall, the project will result in low or 
minimal environmental impacts and will not pose any significant environmental risks. 
 
30.  Involuntary  resettlement  and  indigenous  peoples.  The  project  is  category  C  for 
involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples. No involuntary resettlement or land acquisition 
will result from the project. The plant nursery will be at an existing BOA facility in Nekken, and the 
processing center will be at an existing building owned by the Airai State Government. The project 
will not impact any indigenous peoples as defined under ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement. 
 
G.  Summary of Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan 
 
31.  Overall, the project is low risk because (i) the MOF is experienced in executing ADB grants 
and loans; (ii) the procurement of goods and services will not be complex, and adequate providers 
have been pre-identified; (iii) no safeguard concerns exist; and (iv) the project activities involve 
the modification and expansion of existing practices. Significant financial management risks 
identified and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4 and described in detail in the risk 
assessment and risk management plan.

Contribution to the Strategy 2030 Operational Priorities 
The expected values and methodological details for all OP indicators to which this operation will contribute results are 
detailed in Contribution to Strategy 2030 Operational Priorities (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 
2 of the report and recommendation of the President). In addition to the OP indicators tagged in the design and 
monitoring framework, this operation will contribute results for: 
OP 1.1.3: Social protection schemes established or improved (number). Expected: existing social protection scheme 
for older people improved. Care services for older people are mostly confined to health services; this will be expanded 
to be more holistic, and will include social, physical, and mental aspects of aged care. 
OP 2.1.4: Women and girls benefit from new or improved infrastructure (number). Expected: at least 300 women 
farmers benefit from the agribusiness support center. 
OP 2.4.2: Child and elderly care services established or improved (number). Expected: two existing key aged care 
services improved. 
OP 2.5.4: Dedicated crisis-responding social assistance schemes for women and girls implemented or established 
(number). Expected: at least one social assistance scheme (seed grant) implemented for women to withstand COVID-
19.

metadata.Subject: The project aims to address the needs of poor and vulnerable groups affected by the coronavirus disease (COVID-19). All outputs are aligned with the outcome of improving the capability of vulnerable groups to withstand the impacts of COVID-19 by providing immediate assistance to these groups while positioning them to achieve higher levels of economic and social well-being post-COVID-19.The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.This document dated July 2021 is provided for the ADB project 54196-001 in Palau.
